Articles.Content:
How can I schedule a rendez-vous with an object (like an asteroid) in orbit around the Sun ?

I know how to do a regular rendez-vous in Kerbin orbit but I guess I have to wait for a window to happen in I want to be fuel efficient and using the Oberth effect correctly.

I generally use tools such as Kerbal Alarm Clock to get my transfer windows for other celestial bodies, but I don't know how to do it for asteroids.

Rough and ready version:

You need to escape Kerbin's SOI, burning over sunset for asteroids in a higher orbit than Kerbin or ahead of Kerbin, and over sunrise for asteroids in lower orbits or behind Kerbin. Then once you've left Kerbin's gravity, use a manoeuvre node to plot an intercept, and treat it the same as though you were making an orbital docking in LKO (but it takes way longer and a good bit more fuel).

Thank you but I already know the basics.

What I'm asking is how can I optimize the burn while in orbit around Kerbin so I only have to do little corrections while in Sun orbit.

I see. Well, that will depend completely on their orbit and current position.

I don't know, but I believe mods that calculate this for planets rely on the starting positions of the planets on Y1 D01 0:00 as a datum for working out optimal phasing windows. For asteroids, you'd need the relevant formulae and you'd have to put in the asteroid's orbital parameters, which I'm not sure you can access in enough detail (since they're randomly spawned).

I'm probably not the best informed on this, but I doubt whether that kind of mod or calculator is available, since there are so many variables to consider for a truly 'optimal' burn.
Orbits are defined by only 6 parameters, I think KER give them. I'll check.

Perhaps (I don't use KER), but you need to know the precise orbital parameters for the same time as those for your point of origin. I guess it's theoretically possible to use current time to rewind the asteroid's position to datum time, but again I don't know of any mod or calculator that currently does this.

To be honest this level of mathematics is a bit over my head, so hopefully someone with a better head for numbers will weigh in here!

Edited September 12, 2015 by The_Rocketeer

I don't mind being super efficient too, it's ok to lose something like 100 m/s due to not optimal burn. Usually for interplanetary transfer I just make the approximation of a 70x70 circular orbit, and it's fine, because what's really matter is the angle of ejection.

I checked and KER indeed give the 6 parameters required.

In a shocking coincidence, I was just browsing when I came across this thread - I didn't read it in detail, but it looks like it might do what you're looking for:

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/36476-WIN-MAC-KSP-Trajectory-Optimization-Tool-v1-5-0-Optimizations!

Yes I know this mod, but it's super hard to use.

I tried using a conventional windows calculator by adding a celestial body with the parameters of a lost ship.

It worked quite well for a "flyby", but with a relative speed of 2200 m/s... Meh :/
Boo... well I'm afraid my expertise is pretty much tapped out. Good luck
Axelmoon's Launch Window Planner has a button to add a body. Click it, enter the data for your asteroid, then you can use the tool to calculate transfers as normal.
